detail.content: Open Arts: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Yes! You Can Take Tisch Courses  We’ve all heard the expression “open arms.” At Tisch School of the Arts, we take it one step further. In fact, you’re more likely hear “open arts.” The Tisch Open Arts Curriculum is a series of Tisch courses open to all undergraduate and graduate students at NYU regardless of major or ability.    Once enrolled in these courses, students begin to develop their artistic interests and creativity while receiving introductory exposure, foundational knowledge, and hands-on experience in various artistic fields.             Acting I & II    Acting For The Camera Workshop    The Bard Out Loud: An Introduction To Acting Shakespeare    Fundamentals of Developing The Screenplay    Fundamentals Of Filmmaking: A Digital Workshop Introduction To Digital Tools    Introduction To Special Effects Make-Up    Media Moguls In The 20th Century    Musical Theatre Writing Workshop    Photography I    The Picture Essay For Paper and Pixels    Playwriting Practicum    The Politics Of Portraiture    The Producing Essentials    Steps, Rhythm And Movement of African Dance    Steps, Rhythm And Movement of Indian Dance    Tisch All School Choir: Drama Cantorum    Working With Groups In Community Settings: From Theory To Practice    Topics In South African Culture: History, Culture, Diversity And Expression Through The Literary, Visual and Performing Arts    Use the course number and call number provided with each course to register. It’s that easy. Shirazi: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Administration Tisch Human Resources Computer & Information Technology  home > Administration          Art & Public Policy, Special Programs, Tisch Asia   Pari Sara Shirazi, Ph.D. Associate Arts Professor Phone: 212 998 1520 Email: ps1@nyu.edu Office: 721 Broadway 12FL  Courses Traditions in Narrative   Iranian Cinema   Topics in [Brazil, South Africa, China, Cuba] Culture: History, Culture, and Expression through the Literary, Visual and Performing Arts Education B.A., New York University M.A., Psychology, New York University M.A., Near Eastern Studies, New York University Ph.D., Near Eastern Studies, New York University Biography Pari Sara Shirazi, Ph.D., was named vice dean of Tisch School of the Arts at New York University in 1999. Dr. Shirazi’s expertise in business, finance, and her profound belief in global education yield great benefits for the Tisch community. Her academic research interests include world literature and cinema, artistic expression and cultural traditions of countries in political transition and "mental cinema." Dr. Shirazi is an associate arts professor and teaches Iranian Cinema, Traditions in Narrative, and a course that studies the culture, history and artistic expression of countries such as Brazil, China, Cuba, and South Africa. During her career, Dr. Shirazi has spearheaded the creation of Institute for Artists and Global Change. Under her direction, the Tisch School now sponsors six academic year programs abroad: one in London with the BBC and Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts; in Dublin with Ireland’s leading playwrights and screenwriters; with the University of the Witswatersrand in Johannesburg; in Havana with the Ludwig Foundation of Cuba and the Cuban National Institute of Film and Television (ICAIC); with the Prague Film and Television Academy; and also with the Shanghai Theatre Academy. In addition to the academic year abroad programs, there are summer programs offered through Tisch in many countries, including Czech Republic, England, France, Germany, Ghana, Ireland, Italy, Ireland, and The Netherlands. She is the founder of NYU's International Student Film Festival - Next Reel. Dr. Shirazi also is advocate for providing access to arts education. At the campus in New York, Dr. Shirazi has been instrumental in creating programs that introduces the arts to students majoring in business, science, and economics to the arts. Dr. Shirazi is the visionary behind Tisch School of the Arts Asia and led the effort to establish NYU’s first campus outside New York City. In 2007, she was named president of Tisch School of the Arts Asia, and continues to serve as vice dean.
